text: Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What was the number? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Let’s see the damage. Bom Bom Bom. Patient: I was checking. Doctor: How sugar’s been you think? text: Patient: I thought you said the scans didn’t… Family Member: That’s what you said last month. Healthcare Professional: Last time they had the prelim report, but… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So one of the areas and again like I said I don’t know what to make of this because it is on the bone scan. I thought I – did we talk about this? Okay. Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh) Doctor: So I still think they are because, but what this says is that there is increasing uptake. So since I’m gonna give you these… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: …I wanted you to know. Unfortunately the size are the how bright it is. So increasing uptake means it’s brighter now than it was before. Patient: This is in the bones? Doctor: Correct, yeah. That grade of brightness I guess, doesn’t mean a whole lot for prostate cancer on the bone scan. Okay because even healing bone can look brighter than the other. So on the bone scan really what would tell me that there is progression of the disease would be if there were new areas and there were not. Okay? But I just needed to explain this because- Family Member: Yes.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
